en: At the end of each day, I made a huge pot of soup  which we all shared.
zh: 每一天最后，我都做一大锅汤 大家共享。

en: We worked well into each night.
zh: 每晚都努力工作。

en: Before I close though,  let me tell you about my grandmother.
zh: 在最后让我说说 我的祖母。

en: She grew up at a time  when Confucianism was the social norm  and the local Mandarin was the person who mattered.
zh: 她成长的时代 儒教盛行， 本地Mandarin最大。

en: Her father died soon after she was born.
zh: 她出生的时候，父亲去世，

en: Her mother raised her alone.
zh: 由母亲独自养大。

en: At 17 she became the second wife  of a Mandarin whose mother beat her.
zh: 她17岁嫁给了一个Mandarin， 做二房，遭到婆婆的打骂。

en: With no support from her husband,  she caused a sensation by taking him to court  and prosecuting her own case,  and a far greater sensation when she won.
zh: 没有丈夫的支持， 带着丈夫去法院起诉自己， 从而轰动一时， 胜诉的她更是名声远扬。

en: "It can't be done" was shown to be wrong.
zh: （鼓掌） “不可能”变成了可能。

en: I was taking a shower in a hotel room in Sydney  I looked through the shower screen  and saw her standing on the other side.
zh: 当她在600英里外的墨尔本 逝世时， 我正在悉尼的宾馆房间洗澡。 透过玻璃， 我看到她站在对面。

en: We told her stories  and assured her that we were still with her.
zh: 我们讲述着故事， 向她保证我们一直陪着她。

en: My mother asked us to feel her hand.
zh: 我母亲让我们感受祖母的手。

en: She asked the monk,  "Why is it that her hand is so warm  and the rest of her is so cold?"
zh: 她问僧人 “为什么祖母的手是温的， 其他地方那么凉？”

en: "Because you have been holding it since this morning," he said.
zh: “因为您从早上一直握到现在”，他说

en: "You have not let it go."
zh: “你从未放手”。

en: If there is a sinew in our family,  it runs through the women.
zh: 如果说我们家族有动力， 那它一定来着于妇女们。

en: Given who we were and how life had shaped us,  we can now see  that the men who might have come into our lives  would have thwarted us.
zh: 考虑到我们自身和生活的塑造， 我们现在可以预见， 一个男人必须挫败我们才能融入我们。 必须挫败我们才行。

en: Who could ever wish it on their own?
zh: 又有谁不愿意呢？

en: Can I give them a bow in their lives,  dipping bravely into each wave,  the unperturbed and steady beat of the engine,  the vast horizon  that guarantees nothing?
zh: 给他们生命的桨， 勇敢地划入每个波浪， 自然地、稳稳地发动机， 宽广的视野， 不用任何担保，我能做到吗？

en: But if I could give it  and still see them safely through,  I would.
zh: 但是我可以放任它， 看着他们安全的通过， 这也是我希望的。

en: I was in the desert, under the starry skies  with the Sufi singer Mukhtiar Ali.
zh: 我在沙漠，在一个满是星光的天空下 和一名苏菲派的歌手木泰哈·阿里

en: And we were in conversation  about how nothing had changed  since the time of the ancient Indian epic "The Mahabharata."
zh: 我们的谈话是关于 没有任何事情被改变 自从古代印度史诗《摩呵婆罗多》的时候起

en: So back in the day, when us Indians wanted to travel  we'd jump into a chariot and we'd zoom across the sky.
zh: 回到过去，当我们想去旅游 我们跳进了一个战车飞驰过了天空

en: Back then,  when Arjuna, the great Indian warrior prince,  when he was thirsty, he'd take out a bow,  he'd shoot it into the ground and water would come out.
zh: 在那个时候， 当印度伟大的战王阿朱那， 当他渴了，他拔出一支箭， 射进地里水就会出来

en: I was terrified by this idea  that I would lose the ability  to enjoy and appreciate the sunset  without having my camera on me, without tweeting it to my friends.
zh: 我对这种想法感到恐惧 我将会失去 享受和欣赏日落的能力 在没有相机，没有和我的朋友们微博的情况下

en: It became a gilded gateway  into a world full of pirates and shipwrecks  and images in my imagination.
zh: 在我的想象力中，它变成了一个镀金的大门 带我通向一个充满了海盗和失事船只 和富有想象的世界

en: And so I jumped in, I jumped into this world of technology,  to see how I could use it to enable magic  as opposed to kill it.
zh: 所以我投入进了这个科技的世界， 看看如何能用它们来创造魔法 而不是扼杀它们

en: I've been illustrating books since I was 16.
zh: 我从16岁起就开始为书来作插图

en: And so when I saw the iPad,  I saw it as a storytelling device  that could connect readers all over the world.
zh: 当我看到iPad, 我把它当作一个讲故事的设备 可以将全世界的读者都联系起来

en: And I don't mean wizards and dragons,  I mean the kind of childhood magic,  those ideas that we all harbored as children.
zh: 并不是指巫婆和神龙， 而是指孩子们的魔法， 那些我们孩童时候心存的想法

en: And so over here you need to tilt your iPad,  take the fireflies out.
zh: 在这里你需要倾斜你的iPad, 让这些萤火虫出来

en: Another idea that really fascinated me as a child  was that an entire galaxy could be contained  within a single marble.
zh: 另一个令人着迷的主意就是当我还是个孩子 整个银河系将被 一块大理石包裹着

en: And so over here,  each book and each world  becomes a little marble  that I drag in  to this magical device within the device.
zh: 所以在这里 每一本书都 变成一个小的大理石 我将它们用这个装置 托进这个魔法的装置里面

en: This is a map that grows and glows  and becomes your navigation for the rest of the book.
zh: 这是一张地图变化并且发热 成为你剩下这本书的导航

en: It reveals itself to you at certain points in the book as well.
zh: 在这本书的某处它也会显示出自己

en: Another thing that's actually really important to me  is creating content that is Indian  and yet very contemporary.
zh: 另一个对我而言真的重要的事情就是 创造非常印度 却又非常现代的内容

en: Over here, these are the Apsaras.
zh: 在这里，这些是飞天

en: So we've all heard about fairies and we've all heard about nymphs,  but how many people outside of India  know about their Indian counterparts, the Apsaras?
zh: 我们都听说过仙女，听说过女神， 但是有多少在印度之外的人 知道关于她们的对应者，飞天？

en: And a story that actually deals with new issues  like the environmental crisis.
zh: 一个解决新问题的故事， 如同环境危机

en: But now with mobile technology,  we can actually take our children outside into the natural world  One of the interactions in the book  is that you're sent off on this quest  where you need to go outside,  take out your camera on the iPad  and collect pictures of different natural objects.
zh: 但是现在用移动式的科技， 我们可以用科技 把我们的孩子领出去带到自然世界 在这本书中的一个互动就是 这个要求命令 你需要去到外面世界， 用你iPad上的相机 收集不同的自然物的照片

en: And somehow kids don't do that anymore.
zh: 不知道为什么孩子们不再收集了

en: So in bringing back this childhood ritual,  you need to go out  and, in one chapter, take a picture of a flower  and then tag it.
zh: 所以我把这个孩子时候的仪式带了回来， 你需要走出去 在一个章节里，照一张花儿的照片 然后给它标记命名

en: In the next book, we plan on having an interaction  where you take your iPad out with the video on  and through augmented reality,  you see this layer of animated pixies  appear on a houseplant that's outside your house.
zh: 在下本书中，我们计划一种互动 你用iPad的视频 通过增强现实， 你看这层是活泼乱动的精灵 出现在你房子外面的盆栽上

en: We're moving, we're all moving here,  to a world where the forces of nature  come closer together to technology,  and magic and technology can come closer together.
zh: 我们在移动，移动到这里 到一个自然的力量和科技变得越来越近 的一个世界， 魔法和科技可以走得更近

en: Thank you.
zh: 谢谢

en: And I really think that the most important thing of it  is that we stopped listening to patients.
zh: 我想最重要的一点 是我们没有倾听病人的心声

en: And one of the things we did at Radboud University  is we appointed a chief listening officer.
zh: 我们在荷兰内梅亨大学做的一件事 就是委任了一名首席倾听官

en: Not in a very scientific way --  she puts up a little cup of coffee or cup of tea  and asks patients, family, relatives,  "What's up?
zh: 不是以一种很科学的方式－ 她倒杯咖啡或者茶 问问病人，家庭，亲戚 “近来好啊？

en: How could we help you?"
zh: 有什么需要我们帮助的？”

en: This is my WiFi scale. It's a very simple thing.
zh: 这是我的WiFi体重测量仪 是个很简单的玩意

en: And every morning I hop on it.
zh: 每天早上我坐上去称重

en: And yes, I've got a challenge,  as you might see.
zh: 哈不错，我给自己定了个目标值 你可以看到的

en: And I put my challenge on 95 kg.
zh: 我把体重目标值定为95kg

en: But the thing is that it's made this simple  that whenever I hop on,  it sends my data through Google Health as well.
zh: 事实上整个操作非常简单 我一坐上去 它就把我的数据发送到谷歌健康

en: And it's collected by my general practitioner as well,  so he can see what's my problem in weight,  not on the very moment  that I need cardiologic support or something like it,  but also looking backward.
zh: 同时我的全科医生也可以收到 然后他就能看看我的体重有什么问题 不是等到像心脏病发作 这样十万火急的时候才想到看体重 而是一路走来都会关注

en: But there's another thing.
zh: 但还有一点

en: As some of you might know, I've got more than 4,000 followers on Twitter.
zh: 你们有些人可能知道 我在推特上有四千多粉丝

en: So every morning  I hop on my WiFi scale  and before I'm in my car, people start talking to me,  "I think you need a light lunch today, Lucien."
zh: 所以每天早上 我用WiFi体重测量仪称重 在我上车之前 人们就开始跟我说话了 “我想你今天午饭还是就简吧，吕西安”

en: But that's the nicest thing that could happen,  since this is peer pressure,  peer pressure used to help patients --  since this could be used for obesity,  it could be used  to stop smoking in patients.
zh: 但其实那再好不过了 因为这是同伴压力 同伴压力能帮助病人－ 它可以帮助治疗肥胖 可以帮助 戒烟

en: But on the other hand, it also could be used  to get people from out of their chairs  and try to work together in some kind of gaming activity  to get more control of their health.
zh: 但是另外一方面，它也可以 把人们聚集到一起 参加一些类似游戏的活动 来更好地维护健康

en: As of next week, it will soon be available.
zh: 下一周这个功能就要上马了

en: There will be this little blood pressure meter  connected to an iPhone or something or other.
zh: 届时会有一个像这样的小血压计 连接到智能手机或者其他设备上

en: And people will be able, from their homes,  to take their blood pressure,  send it into their doctor  and eventually share it with others, for instance,  for over a hundred dollars.
zh: 然后人们便可在家中 测量血压 之后把数据发给他们的医生 同时也可同其他人分享 只要一百美元

en: And this is the point where patients get into position  and can collect, not only their own control again,  be captain of their own ship,  but also can help us in health care  due to the challenges that we face,  like health care cost explosion,  doubled demand and things like that.
zh: 这就是关键之处，当患者各就各位 收集数据时，他们不仅能自我控制 亲自掌舵 还能帮助我们应付 医疗保健中面临的挑战 比如医疗费用剧增 或者需求成倍增加等等

en: Make techniques that are easy to use  and start with this to embrace patients in the team.
zh: 我们要让技术便于掌控 以鼓励已步入轨道的病人

en: And you can do this with techniques like this,  but also by crowd-sourcing.
zh: 你可以通过这样的技术来实现 也可以将任务分派给普通大众

en: We've all got navigation controls in our car.
zh: 我们车里都有导航装置

en: We maybe even [have] it in our cellphone.
zh: 甚至手机里也有

en: The other thing is we know where all the gas stations are.
zh: 也知道所有加油站的位置

en: And sure, we could find fast food chains.
zh: 当然还有快餐店

en: But where would be the nearest AED  to help this patient?
zh: 但是最近的能拯救患者的 自动体外除颤器在哪儿？

en: We asked around and nobody knew.
zh: 我们到处问也没有人知道

en: Nobody knew where the nearest life-saving AED  was to be obtained right now.
zh: 没人知道的能救命的自动体外除颤器 现在能找到了

en: So what we did, we crowdsourced The Netherlands.
zh: 我们将属于整个荷兰的任务派发给群众

en: We set up a website  and asked the crowd, "If you see an AED,  please submit it, tell us where it is,  tell us when it's open,"  since sometimes in office hours sometimes it's closed, of course.
zh: 我们建了一个网站 告诉人们，“如果你看到一个自动体外除颤器 就请在网上标出它的位置 并备注开放时间” 备注是因为它不一定24小时都开放

en: The next step we took was to find the applications for it.
zh: 下一步就是开发相应的应用程序

en: We made an application for Layar, augmented reality,  to find these AEDs.
zh: 一个Layar的应用，扩增实境 来寻找AED

en: And whenever you are in a city like Maastricht and somebody collapses,  you can use your iPhone,  and within the next weeks also run your Microsoft cellphone,  to find the nearest AED  which can save lives.
zh: 如果你在马斯特里赫特市 看到有人倒下了 你可以用iPhone 几周之内微软手机也可以了 找到最近的AED 来拯救生命

en: And as of today,  we would like to introduce this, not only as AED4EU,  which is what the product is called,  but also AED4US.
zh: 今天 我想介绍的，不仅仅是AED4U 这是那个产品的名字 还有aed4.us

en: And we would like to start this on a worldwide level.
zh: 我们打算将这项目推广到全世界

en: That whenever you're on holiday and somebody collapses,  might it be your own relative or someone just in front of you,  you can find this.
zh: 这样当你假日外出看见有人昏倒了 也许是你的亲人或者只是路人 你就能找到AED

en: These might be courier services  or cable guys for instance,  just to see whether the AED that's submitted  still is in place.
zh: 譬如，或许让快递员 或者电报员 去看看被标识的AED 是不是还在那个位置

en: So please help us on this one  and try to make not only health a little bit better, but take control of it.
zh: 所以请在这一项目上帮助我们 让我们不仅更健康，并且能将其掌握，胸有成竹

en: I'm here to share my photography.
zh: 今天我想在此跟大家分享一下我的摄影作品

en: Or is it photography?
zh: 或者说，这张也是摄影作品么？

en: Because, of course, this is a photograph  that you can't take with your camera.
zh: 因为，这显然是一张照片 但却是你用相机拍不出来的

en: It mixed with my earlier passion for drawing,  but it was a bit different,  because using the camera,  the process was in the planning instead.
zh: 这里面夹杂了我之前对绘画的热爱 但是有一点不一样 因为使用照相机的时候 整个过程已经提前计划好了

en: So to me it felt like photography was more about  being at the right place and the right time.
zh: 所以在我看来摄影更注重 适当的拍摄地点和时间

en: I felt like anyone could do that.
zh: 我觉得任何人都可以做这件事

en: So I wanted to create something different,  something where the process starts  when you press the trigger.
zh: 所以我想做点特别的 特别之处就在于当你摁下快门时 整个过程才刚刚开始

en: Photos like this:  construction going on along a busy road.
zh: 比如这张照片： 一条繁忙的公路旁边正在进行施工

en: But it has an unexpected twist.
zh: （题材平凡，）但手法出人意料

en: Or photos like these --  both dark and colorful,  but all with a common goal  of retaining the level of realism.
zh: 或者像这样的照片 既有暗色也有彩色 但是其目的都是 为了保留一份现实主义感

en: When I say realism,  I mean photo-realism.
zh: 我说的现实主义 指的是照片的现实主义

en: Because, of course,  it's not something you can capture really,  but I always want it to look like it could have been captured somehow  as a photograph.
zh: 因为这的确 不是你可以真正抓住的东西 但是我总想让它看起来像是可以用某种方式 被抓拍下来一样

en: Photos where you will need a brief moment to think  to figure out the trick.
zh: 这些照片需要你能够快速 找出它们背后的技巧

en: So it's more about capturing an idea  than about capturing a moment really.
zh: 所以更注重的是捕捉一个灵感 而不是捕捉一个真实存在的瞬间

en: But what's the trick  that makes it look realistic?
zh: 但是使这些照片看起来 很写实的技巧是什么呢？

en: Is it something about the details  or the colors?
zh: 是关于细节？ 还是关于色彩？

en: Is it something about the light?
zh: 还是关于光线？

en: But in the end, it comes down to how we interpret the world  and how it can be realized on a two-dimensional surface.
zh: 但最终，还是要归结于我们如何理解这个世界 以及这种理解如何在一个二维空间得以体现

en: It's not really what is realistic,  it's what we think looks realistic really.
zh: 这并不是关于什么是真的 而是关于我们认为什么看起来像是真的

en: And let me show you a simple example.
zh: 让我来举个简单的例子

en: Here we have three perfectly imaginable physical objects,  something we all can relate to living in a three-dimensional world.
zh: 这里有三个完全可想象到并真实存在的物体 我们可以在现实的三维世界里找到它们

en: But combined in a certain way,  they can create something that still looks three-dimensional,  like it could exist.
zh: 但若将这些物体用某种方式组合起来 就可以创造出视觉上依然是三维的物体 就好像它是会存在的

en: So we trick our brains,  because our brain simply doesn't accept the fact  that it doesn't really make sense.
zh: 就这样我们骗了自己的大脑 因为大脑就是不肯接受 这个物体其实并不存在这一事实

en: It's just really about combining different realities.
zh: 也是如此 确实只是把不同的现实画面组合起来

en: So the things that make a photograph look realistic,  I think it's the things that we don't even think about,  the things all around us in our daily lives.
zh: 所以使一张照片看起来逼真的事物 是那些我们平时甚至不会去想 但在日常生活中随处可见的东西

en: But when combining photographs,  this is really important to consider,  because otherwise it just looks wrong somehow.
zh: 但是当我们组合照片的时候 这点就值得我们着重思考了 否则它看起来就会别扭

en: But combined, they can create something like this.
zh: 但是组合起来，它们就可以创造出这样的画面

en: The third one is about making it impossible to distinguish  where the different images begin and end  by making it seamless.
zh: 第三个原则是要让人难以分辨 这些不同照片的衔接点 使衔接看起来天衣无缝

en: Make it impossible to say  how the image actually was composed.
zh: 使任何人都道不出 这图片是如何创作而成的

en: So here's another example.
zh: 这里还有一个例子

en: One might think that this is just an image of a landscape  and the lower part is what's manipulated.
zh: 有人可能认为这只是一张风景图 下面的部分是处理过的

en: I personally think that it's easier to actually create a place  than to find a place,  because then you don't need to compromise  with the ideas in your head.
zh: 我个人认为创造一个地方比找到一个地方 要容易一些 因为你不用 与自己大脑的想法妥协

en: And getting this idea during winter,  I knew that I had several months to plan it,  to find the different locations  for the pieces of the puzzle basically.
zh: 去年冬天产生这个想法时 我知道我有几个月的时间去规划这件事 基本上要到不同的地点 找这一拼图所需的图片

en: So to achieve a realistic result,  I think it comes down to planning.
zh: 为了达到一个逼真的效果 我认为最重要的就是规划

en: It always starts with a sketch, an idea.
zh: 总是会先出现一个大概的构思和想法

en: Then it's about combining the different photographs.
zh: 然后就是组合不同的照片

en: And here every piece is very well planned.
zh: 这里每一个图片都是经过仔细规划的

en: So all the tools are out there,  and the only thing that limits us  is our imagination.
zh: 所以其实所有的工具都在那 唯一限制我们的 是我们的想象力

en: Because I usually take the role  of trying to explain to people  how wonderful the new technologies  that are coming along are going to be,  and I thought that, since I was among friends here,  I would tell you what I really think  and try to look back and try to understand  what is really going on here  with these amazing jumps in technology  that seem so fast that we can barely keep on top of it.
zh: 由于我经常 向人们解释 即将到来的新科技 将会多么的美妙 我想既然我跟各位朋友们一起在这 就让我来说说我真正的想法 并试着回顾和理解 这到底是如何发生的 有了这些科技上的惊人进步。 科技的进步似乎快到我们根本无法赶上它的脚步。

en: So I'm going to start out  by showing just one very boring technology slide.
zh: 让我先从这开始 一页很无趣的科技幻灯片。

en: And then, so if you can just turn on the slide that's on.
zh: 然后可以开始放幻灯片了。

en: And the interesting thing about it  is that this slide,  like so many technology slides that we're used to,  is a sort of a straight line  on a semi-log curve.
zh: 有趣的是 这页幻灯片 就像很多我们所熟悉的幻灯片一样， 是半对数曲线图 上的一条直线。

en: In other words, every step here  represents an order of magnitude  in performance scale.
zh: 也就是这里的每一层， 代表了性能程度 大小的一级。

en: And this is a new thing  that we talk about technology  on semi-log curves.
zh: 在半对数曲线图上 讨论科技， 这很新鲜。

en: Something really weird is going on here.
zh: 这其中有点奇特。

en: And that's basically what I'm going to be talking about.
zh: 这基本上是我接下来要说的。

en: So, if you could bring up the lights.
zh: 麻烦开一下灯。

en: If you could bring up the lights higher,  because I'm just going to use a piece of paper here.
zh: 请把灯开亮点， 因为我要用张纸。

en: Well the answer is, if I drew it on a normal curve  where, let's say, this is years,  this is time of some sort,  and this is whatever measure of the technology  that I'm trying to graph,  the graphs look sort of silly.
zh: 嗯，答案是，如果我用普通曲线画， 我们说，这是年份， 这是某个时间， 这是我准备画的 科技的某种测量值， 这图看起来有点傻。

en: They sort of go like this.
zh: 就有点像是这样。

en: And they don't tell us much.
zh: 而且并没有提供什么资讯。

en: Now if I graph, for instance,  some other technology, say transportation technology,  on a semi-log curve,  it would look very stupid, it would look like a flat line.
zh: 现在，如果我画，比如说， 另一种技术，像是交通运输， 在半对数曲线上， 它看起来很蠢，会像条很平的线。

en: But when something like this happens,  things are qualitatively changing.
zh: 但是如果出现像这种 质变的情况。

en: It's not moving like that. And there's nothing precedented  in the history of technology development  of this kind of self-feeding growth  where you go by orders of magnitude every few years.
zh: 但它并没有进步得那么快。 在科技发展历史中 也没有任何 这种自给自足， 每几年程度翻倍增长的先例。

en: Now the question that I'd like to ask is,  if you look at these exponential curves,  they don't go on forever.
zh: 现在我想要问的是， 如果你观察这些指数曲线， 它们并非永远的持续下去。

en: Things just can't possibly keep changing  as fast as they are.
zh: 事物不可能一直 改变得那么快。

en: Either it's going to turn into a sort of classical S-curve like this,  until something totally different comes along,  or maybe it's going to do this.
zh: 要么它会变成像这样典型的S曲线 直到完全不同的情况出现。 或是会变成这样。

en: That's about all it can do.
zh: 这就是所有可能。

en: Now I'm an optimist,  so I sort of think it's probably going to do something like that.
zh: 现在我是个乐观主义者， 所以我觉得它很有可能就会变成这样。

en: If so, that means that what we're in the middle of right now  is a transition.
zh: 如果是这样，意味着我们目前所在的 是过渡阶段。

en: We're sort of on this line  in a transition from the way the world used to be  to some new way that the world is.
zh: 我们似乎在这条线上， 在世界从过去 到将来的转变中。

en: And so what I'm trying to ask, what I've been asking myself,  is what's this new way that the world is?
zh: 所有我要问的，我一直在问自己的， 就是这世界未来道路在哪？

en: What's that new state that the world is heading toward?
zh: 它趋向的新时代是什么样的？

en: Because the transition seems very, very confusing  when we're right in the middle of it.
zh: 由于这个变化似乎非常，非常迷惑人， 当我们正处于其中时。

en: Now here's a conference  in which people talk about the future,  and you notice that the future is still at about the year 2000.
zh: 现在这个会议上， 大家在讨论未来， 而且你能发现这未来指的还是那个“2000年”。

en: It's about as far as we go out.
zh: 这就是我们能达到的程度。

en: Now I think that the reason  is because we all feel  that something's happening there.
zh: 我想原因是 我们都感觉到 正在发生些什么。

en: That transition is happening. We can all sense it.
zh: 变化正在发生。我们都能察觉到。

en: And we know that it just doesn't make too much sense  to think out 30, 50 years  because everything's going to be so different  that a simple extrapolation of what we're doing  just doesn't make any sense at all.
zh: 我们知道去考虑那未来的三、五十年 已经没什么意义了， 因为每件事都将如此不同 以至于推测将来 不再有意义。

en: So what I would like to talk about  is what that could be,  what that transition could be that we're going through.
zh: 所以我要聊聊 那会是怎样， 我们正在经历的转变会是怎样。

en: Now in order to do that  I'm going to have to talk about a bunch of stuff  that really has nothing to do  with technology and computers.
zh: 为达到这个目的， 我得介绍一堆东西 它们与 科技和电脑完全无关。

en: Because I think the only way to understand this  is to really step back  and take a long time scale look at things.
zh: 因为我决定理解这个的唯一方法 就是回顾过去 拉长时间轴去看。

en: So the time scale that I would like to look at this on  is the time scale of life on Earth.
zh: 而我所要看的时间轴 是以地球上生命的时间跨度来看。

en: So I think this picture makes sense  if you look at it a few billion years at a time.
zh: 我想这幅图合理了 如果你每次从几十亿年跨度来看。

en: So if you go back  about two and a half billion years,  the Earth was this big, sterile hunk of rock  with a lot of chemicals floating around on it.
zh: 所以如果你回溯个 大概25亿年， 地球这么大，贫瘠的大块石头 上面浮着些化学物质。

en: And if you look at the way  that the chemicals got organized,  we begin to get a pretty good idea of how they do it.
zh: 要是观察 这些化学物质怎样组合的， 我们开始弄明白它们怎么形成的。

en: And I think that there's theories that are beginning to understand  about how it started with RNA,  but I'm going to tell a sort of simple story of it,  which is that, at that time,  there were little drops of oil floating around  with all kinds of different recipes of chemicals in them.
zh: 我想有些理论是从理解 生命怎样从核糖核酸演变开始， 但是我想讲一个生命的简单故事， 就是，在那个时候， 有一滴滴的油四处浮动， 里面有各种不同化学成分组合。

en: And some of those drops of oil  had a particular combination of chemicals in them  which caused them to incorporate chemicals from the outside  and grow the drops of oil.
zh: 有些油滴 里面含有特殊的化学构成 这导致它们可以从外界聚集化学物质 并慢慢变大。

en: And those that were like that  started to split and divide.
zh: 像这样的油滴 又开始分化，分离。

en: And those were the most primitive forms of cells in a sense,  those little drops of oil.
zh: 最原始的那些在某种程度上形成了细胞， 这些小小的油滴。

en: But now those drops of oil weren't really alive, as we say it now,  because every one of them  was a little random recipe of chemicals.
zh: 但目前为止这些油滴不是真正活着的，在我们现在看来， 因为每一个 都是化学物质的随机合成。

en: And every time it divided,  they got sort of unequal division  of the chemicals within them.
zh: 每分裂一次， 都不是平均分布 内部的化学物。

en: In fact, the drops that were different in a way  that caused them to be better  at incorporating chemicals around them,  grew more and incorporated more chemicals and divided more.
zh: 实际上，油滴不同的方式 是让它们能更好地 集成周围的化合物， 长得更大，吸收更多，分裂更多。

en: Now that's sort of just a very simple  chemical form of life,  but when things got interesting  was when these drops  learned a trick about abstraction.
zh: 这就有点像个很简单的 生命的化学形式， 但过程变得有趣 是当这些油滴 学会了一个提供资讯的技巧时。

en: Somehow by ways that we don't quite understand,  these little drops learned to write down information.
zh: 不知怎么用我们不能完全理解的方式， 这些小油滴学会了记录资讯。

en: They learned to record the information  that was the recipe of the cell  onto a particular kind of chemical  called DNA.
zh: 它们学会把 细胞形成的秘诀 记录到一种特殊物质上， 叫做去氧核糖核酸。

en: So in other words, they worked out,  in this mindless sort of evolutionary way,  a form of writing that let them write down what they were,  so that that way of writing it down could get copied.
zh: 也就是说，它们想出了， 以这种随性的进化方式， 可以写下它们基因信息的记录方式， 以便这种记录方式能被复制。

en: In fact, one of the things that I did  just for amusement purposes  is we can now write things in this code.
zh: 实际上，我所做的 仅是为了娱乐效果的一件事 就是我们能用这个代码记录事件。

en: And I've got here a little 100 micrograms of white powder,  which I try not to let the security people see at airports.
zh: 我这有100微克的白粉， 我尽力不让机场安检人员发现它们。

en: But this has in it --  what I did is I took this code --  the code has standard letters that we use for symbolizing it --  and I wrote my business card onto a piece of DNA  and amplified it 10 to the 22 times.
zh: 不过这里面有代码 我所做的是我拿着这代码 它里面有我们用来标记它的标准字母， 然后我把我的名片写到一条去氧核糖核酸上 再放大10到22倍。

en: So if anyone would like a hundred million copies of my business card,  I have plenty for everyone in the room,  and, in fact, everyone in the world,  and it's right here.
zh: 所以如果有人需要数百万份我的名片， 我有足够多份给在座每个人， 甚至是全世界每个人， 就在这。

en: If I had really been a egotist,  I would have put it into a virus and released it in the room.
zh: 要是我是个自大的人， 我就会把它放到病毒里散布到屋子中。

en: And that caused these cells --  that kept them happy for another billion years.
zh: 它导致了细胞的形成—— 让它们又高兴了几十亿年。

en: But then there was another really interesting step  where things became completely different,  which is these cells started exchanging and communicating information,  so that they began to get communities of cells.
zh: 不过还有个很有趣的环节 事情开始变得完全不同， 那就是这些细胞开始交换和交流资讯， 从而形成细胞团体。

en: I don't know if you know this,  but bacteria can actually exchange DNA.
zh: 我不知道你们是否知道这个， 细菌实际上就可以交换去氧核糖核酸。

en: Now that's why, for instance,  antibiotic resistance has evolved.
zh: 这就是为什么，比如， 演变出抗菌免疫。

en: So they survived  or they failed together,  which means that if a community was very successful,  all the individuals in that community  were repeated more  and they were favored by evolution.
zh: 因此它们一起幸存下来 或者一起死去， 也就是说如果一个群落成功了， 所有群落里的个体 都能复制更多， 进化得更有利。

en: And so the next stage that's interesting in life  took about another billion years.
zh: 生命中下一个有趣的阶段 又要几十亿年。

en: And at that stage,  we have multi-cellular communities,  communities of lots of different types of cells,  working together as a single organism.
zh: 在这个时期， 有多细胞族群， 就是有很多种不同细胞的群落， 作为有机体一起合作。

en: Your skin cell is really useless  without a heart cell, muscle cell,  a brain cell and so on.
zh: 皮肤细胞根本没用， 要是没有心脏细胞，肌肉细胞， 脑细胞等等。

en: So these communities began to evolve  so that the interesting level on which evolution was taking place  was no longer a cell,  but a community which we call an organism.
zh: 所以这些族群开始进化 这样发生有趣的进化的 不再仅仅是单一细胞。 而是我们称为有机体的族群。

en: Now the next step that happened  is within these communities.
zh: 接下来发生 就是在这些族群中。

en: And they began building very special structures  that did nothing but process information within the community.
zh: 它们开始构建非常特别的 专门处理群落内资讯的结构。

en: And in fact, they began to get specialists in the community  and special structures  that were responsible for recording,  understanding, learning information.
zh: 实际上，群落里开始出现专家 以及特殊结构 负责记录， 理解，学习资讯。

en: And that was the brains and the nervous system  And that gave them an evolutionary advantage.
zh: 这就是这些细胞群的 大脑和神经系统。 这给了它们进化的有利条件。

en: So an organism could, for instance,  learn not to eat a certain kind of fruit  because it tasted bad and it got sick last time it ate it.
zh: 所以一个有机体能够，比如说， 学会不吃某种水果 因为它不好吃而且上次吃的觉得恶心。

en: That could happen within the lifetime of a single organism,  whereas before they'd built these special information processing structures,  that would have had to be learned evolutionarily  over hundreds of thousands of years  by the individuals dying off that ate that kind of fruit.
zh: 这可以发生在一个单个有机体的一生中， 然后在这种特殊信息处理结构建成前， 这得要进化学习 千万年， 通过吃了这种水果前仆后继死去的个体。

en: So that nervous system,  the fact that they built these special information structures,  tremendously sped up the whole process of evolution.
zh: 所以神经系统， 生物组建这种特殊结构的事实， 极大地加速了进化的进程。

en: But then what happened  was the individuals worked out,  of course, tricks of communicating.
zh: 但是接下来发生的 是每个个体发现了， 当然，交流的秘诀。

en: It's really a pretty amazing invention if you think about it.
zh: 想想看，这真是个奇妙的发明。

en: Here I have a very complicated, messy,  confused idea in my head.
zh: 我脑子里有个很复杂，混乱， 疑惑的想法。

en: But we're taking something very complicated,  turning it into sound, sequences of sounds,  and producing something very complicated in your brain.
zh: 但是我们正在把很复杂的东西 转化成声音，一连串的声音， 并在你们大脑产生很复杂的东西。

en: And so, in fact, what we've done  is we, humanity,  have started abstracting out.
zh: 所以，实际上，我们已经完成的 就是我们，人类， 开始抽离出来。

en: Telephony, computers,  videotapes, CD-ROMs and so on  are all our specialized mechanisms  that we've now built within our society  for handling that information.
zh: 电话，电脑， 影碟，光碟等等 都是我们的特殊机制， 我们正在社会里构建 用来处理资讯的机制。

en: And it all connects us together  into something  that is much bigger  and much faster  and able to evolve  So now, evolution can take place  on a scale of microseconds.
zh: 这些都是把我们联系在一起， 变的 比我们之前 更大， 更快， 更有能力进化。 所以，现在进化可以发生在 微妙的时间跨度级上。

en: So the first steps of the story that I told you about  took a billion years a piece.
zh: 我讲的故事的第一步 每一步花费了几十亿年。

en: The process is feeding on itself  and becoming, I guess, autocatalytic is the word for it --  when something reinforces its rate of change.
zh: 这个过程是自给自足， 并且变成，我猜，应该自我催化描述更合适—— 当事物加快改变的速度。

en: The more it changes, the faster it changes.
zh: 变化越多，变化就越快。

en: And I think that that's what we're seeing here in this explosion of curve.
zh: 我想这就是我们在这看到的激增曲线。

en: Now I design computers for a living,  and I know that the mechanisms  that I use to design computers  would be impossible  without recent advances in computers.
zh: 我现在工作就是自己设计电脑， 我知道用来设计电脑的 这些机制 不可能存在， 要是没有近期电脑的进步。

en: So right now, what I do  is I design objects at such complexity  that it's really impossible for me to design them in the traditional sense.
zh: 现在，我做的 是设计复杂到 不可能从传统意义上设计的物体。

en: I don't know what every transistor in the connection machine does.
zh: 我不知道连接机器上每个电晶体的作用。

en: There are billions of them.
zh: 有几十亿电晶体。

en: Instead, what I do  and what the designers at Thinking Machines do  is we think at some level of abstraction  and then we hand it to the machine  and the machine takes it beyond what we could ever do,  much farther and faster than we could ever do.
zh: 实际上，我所做的 思考机器的设计师们做的， 我们认为是为某种程度的资讯抽取， 然后把它传给机器 而机器把它运用到超出我们所能做的范围， 而且比我们从前所做的更深远更快。

en: And in fact, sometimes it takes it by methods  that we don't quite even understand.
zh: 实际上，有时候它采用的方法 我们并不很懂。

en: One method that's particularly interesting  that I've been using a lot lately  is evolution itself.
zh: 有个尤其有趣 我最近一直在用的 就是进化本身。

en: So what we do  is we put inside the machine  a process of evolution  that takes place on the microsecond time scale.
zh: 我们做的就是 在机器里 放入一个进化进程， 这个进程在微妙时间跨度上就能发生。

en: Now would you please run all of those random sequences of instructions,  run all of those programs,  and pick out the ones that came closest to doing what I wanted."
zh: 现在请你运行所有这些随机指令列， 运行所有程式， 并选出最接近我想要的。”

en: Let's say I want to sort numbers,  as a simple example I've done it with.
zh: 假设我需要分类资料， 这是个我用它试验过的简单例子。

en: So find the programs that come closest to sorting numbers.
zh: 找到最接近资料分类的程式。

en: So of course, random sequences of instructions  are very unlikely to sort numbers,  so none of them will really do it.
zh: 当然，随机的指令序列 非常不可能分类资料， 所以它们中没有一个能完成。

en: But one of them, by luck,  may put two numbers in the right order.
zh: 但是中间有一个，运气很好， 可能会把两个数按顺序排列。

en: And I say, "Computer,  would you please now take the 10 percent  of those random sequences that did the best job.
zh: 我说，“电脑， 请你现在选出序列中百分之十 完成得最好的。

en: And now let's reproduce  the ones that sorted numbers the best.
zh: 现在来复制 资料分类得最好的这些。

en: And let's reproduce them by a process of recombination  analogous to sex."
zh: 以类似交配的重组过程 来复制它们。

en: So I've got now a new generation of programs  that are produced by combinations  of the programs that did a little bit better job.
zh: 所以我得到新一代的 由组合做的比较好的程式 而产生的程式。

en: Score them again.
zh: 再做一次。

en: And try that again and do that for another generation.
zh: 再试一次并用在新的一代上。

en: So I can do the equivalent  of millions of years of evolution on that  or in the complicated cases, in a few hours.
zh: 所以我在电脑上用几分钟 能做等同于 几百万年的进化过程， 或者，情况复杂时，在几小时内完成。

en: At the end of that, I end up with programs  that are absolutely perfect at sorting numbers.
zh: 结束时，我得到 绝对完美的分类资料的程式。

en: In fact, they are programs that are much more efficient  than programs I could have ever written by hand.
zh: 实际上，这些程式比我手写的 任何程式都要有效率。

en: Now if I look at those programs,  I can't tell you how they work.
zh: 现在，如果我读这些程式， 我说不出它们怎么工作的。

en: I've tried looking at them and telling you how they work.
zh: 我尝试过阅读并且解释它们如何工作的。

en: And in fact, I know, I'm very confident that they do the job  because they come from a line  of hundreds of thousands of programs that did the job.
zh: 实际上，我知道，我很有信心，它们能完成任务 因为它们来自于一行 上千万能完成认为的程式。

en: It says, 'This plane has hundreds of thousands of tiny parts  working together to make you a safe flight.'  Doesn't that make you feel confident?"
zh: 这上面说，‘本飞机有很多精密部件 协作，保障你飞行安全。’ 这是不是让你很有信心？”

en: In fact, we know that the engineering process doesn't work very well  when it gets complicated.
zh: 事实上，我们知道工程过程复杂化 并不能很好工作。

en: So we're beginning to depend on computers  to do a process that's very different than engineering.
zh: 所以我们开始依赖电脑 来做与工程有很大不同的一个过程。

en: And it lets us produce things of much more complexity  than normal engineering lets us produce.
zh: 它能让我们生产出 比普通工程能生产的更复杂的东西。

en: So in a sense, it's getting ahead of us.
zh: 从某种意义上说，电脑比我们超前。

en: We're now using those programs  to make much faster computers  so that we'll be able to run this process much faster.
zh: 我们现在正用这些程式 创造更快的电脑 以便能更快地运行这个进程。

en: Because all of these technologies are feeding back on themselves.
zh: 由于所有这些技术都回馈给自己。

en: And what we are is we're at a point in time  which is analogous to when single-celled organisms  were turning into multi-celled organisms.
zh: 我们正是在时间的某一点， 这一点类似于单细胞有机体 正转变成多细胞机体的时刻。

en: So we're the amoebas  and we can't quite figure out what the hell this thing is we're creating.
zh: 我们就像变形虫。 搞不清自己正在创造的是什么东西。

en: But I think that there really is something coming along after us.
zh: 不过我认为一定有跟随着我们的东西。

en: And I think all of us here  are a part of producing  whatever that next thing is.
zh: 我认为我们这所有人 都是繁衍的一部分， 无论下一步是什么。

en: So lunch is coming along,  and I think I will stop at that point,  before I get selected out.
zh: 午饭时间快到了， 趁我还没被选走， 我想我就在这里结束。

en: I think we have to do something  about a piece of the culture of medicine that has to change.
zh: 我觉得在当今的医学文化中， 有一部份文化必须要开始改变。

en: And I think it starts with one physician, and that's me.
zh: 而这个改变可以从一个医生开始，那就是我。

en: And maybe I've been around long enough  that I can afford to give away some of my false prestige  to be able to do that.
zh: 或许是因为我已经行医多年， 我可以承受放弃一些虚无的名利 来开始这样的改变。

en: Before I actually begin the meat of my talk,  let's begin with a bit of baseball.
zh: 在进入主题之前， 让我们先谈谈棒球吧。

en: We're near the end, we're getting close to the World Series.
zh: 常规赛季就快结束，世界职业棒球大赛即将开始。

en: We all love baseball, don't we?
zh: 我们都喜爱棒球，不是吗？

en: And there's hundreds of them.
zh: 让人咋舌的统计数据。

en: "Moneyball" is about to come out, and it's all about statistics  and using statistics to build a great baseball team.
zh: 即将上映的电影 “点球成金”，便是完全关于统计数据， 以及如何在这些数据的基础上建造一个伟大的球队。

en: It's called batting average.
zh: 叫做击球率。

en: So we talk about a 300, a batter who bats 300.
zh: 当我们说一名挥棒球员的击球率为三成的时候，

en: That means hit the ball into the outfield,  it dropped, it didn't get caught,  and whoever tried to throw it to first base didn't get there in time  and the runner was safe.
zh: 安打意味着球会被击中并被打入外野， 而且并不会被立刻接杀， 球也不会在跑者成功上到一垒之前 被及时的传回。

en: Do you know what they call a 300 hitter  in Major League Baseball?
zh: 各位知道棒球大联盟如何评论 这些击球率上了三成的球员吗？

en: Do you know what they call  a 400 baseball hitter?
zh: 各位知道他们又是如何称呼一位 击球率有着四成，

en: That's somebody who hit, by the way,  four times safely out of every 10.
zh: 也就是每十次打击 就会打出四个安打的球员吗。

en: Legendary --  as in Ted Williams legendary --  the last Major League Baseball player  to hit over 400 during a regular season.
zh: 是传奇 -- 像泰德. 威廉斯那样的传奇-- 他是棒球大联盟里最后一个在常规赛中 拥有超过四成击球率的球员。

en: Now let's take this back into my world of medicine  where I'm a lot more comfortable,  or perhaps a bit less comfortable  after what I'm going to talk to you about.
zh: 现在让我们回到我的世界 - 医疗领域。 这个领域我比较熟悉， 但我接下来要说的 却让我有些困扰。

en: Suppose you have appendicitis  and you're referred to a surgeon  who's batting 400 on appendectomies.
zh: 假设你得了阑尾炎， 然后你被推荐给了一位 在阑尾移除手术中有着四成“击球率”的外科医生。

en: Somehow this isn't working out, is it?
zh: 这听起来怪怪的，对吧？

en: Now suppose you live  in a certain part of a certain remote place  and you have a loved one  who has blockages in two coronary arteries  and your family doctor refers that loved one to a cardiologist  who's batting 200 on angioplasties.
zh: 又假设你住在 某一个较为偏远的地区， 而你所爱的人的 两条冠状动脉都被堵塞。 你的家庭医生将她推荐给了一位在血管成形手术上 有着两成“击球率”的心脏科医师。

en: But, but, you know what?
zh: 但是，等等，你知道吗？

en: But I'm going to ask you a question.
zh: 而我现在想问各位一个问题。

en: What do you think a batting average  for a cardiac surgeon or a nurse practitioner  or an orthopedic surgeon,  an OBGYN, a paramedic  is supposed to be?
zh: 你们认为， 一位心脏外科医生，或一位职业护理师， 一位骨科外科医生 妇产科医生或急救人员的 “击球率” 应该是多少？

en: Now truth of the matter is,  nobody knows in all of medicine  what a good surgeon  or physician or paramedic  is supposed to bat.
zh: 事实上， 医学界中没有人知道 一个好的外科医生， 医师或急救人员 应该有多少的 “击球率”。

en: What we do though is we send each one of them, including myself,  out into the world  with the admonition, be perfect.
zh: 我们将他们每个人，包括我自己， 送上职业岗位后 便告诫他们以完美来要求自己 --

en: Never ever, ever make a mistake,  but you worry about the details, about how that's going to happen.
zh: 绝对，绝对不能作出错误的诊断 -- 但我们让他们自己考虑细节，考虑如何达到这样的标准。

en: And that was the message that I absorbed  when I was in med school.
zh: 这就是我在医学院时 得到的信息。

en: And I memorized everything.
zh: 我背下了所有东西。

en: I memorized in my anatomy class  the origins and exertions of every muscle,  every branch of every artery that came off the aorta,  differential diagnoses obscure and common.
zh: 我背下了解剖课中 提到的每一块肌肉的起端和伸展方式， 每一条从主动脉延伸出来的动脉的分支系统， 以及一切鲜为人知的或者常见的鉴别诊断。

en: And I did well, I graduated with honors,  And I came out of medical school  with the impression  that if I memorized everything and knew everything,  or as much as possible,  as close to everything as possible,  that it would immunize me against making mistakes.
zh: 我的表现很好， 并以优等的成绩毕业。 当我从医学院出来时， 我觉得 我只要记下和明白了所有的东西 – 或者稍退一步 – 将近所有的东西， 那我犯医疗错误的几率就会微乎其微。

en: for a while,  until I met Mrs. Drucker.
zh: 而我在一段时间之内 的确没有犯错。 直到我遇到了 Drucker 女士。

en: And it was my job,  when the emergency staff called for a cardiology consult,  to see that patient in emerg.
zh: 我的工作是， 当紧急救护人员需要有关于心脏的专业会诊时， 在急症室诊断病人，

en: And when I listened to her, she was making a wheezy sound.
zh: 在我与她交谈时，我听到她的呼吸有喘息的声音。

en: And when I listened to her chest with a stethoscope,  I could hear crackly sounds on both sides  that told me that she was in congestive heart failure.
zh: 当我用听诊器聆听她的胸腔时， 两边都传来的爆裂的声音告诉我， 这是郁血性心脏衰竭。

en: This is a condition in which the heart fails,  and instead of being able to pump all the blood forward,  some of the blood backs up into the lung, the lungs fill up with blood,  and that's why you have shortness of breath.
zh: 这是由于心脏在衰竭后， 无法将所有的血液完全的输送出去， 而导致部分血液回流入肺脏。肺脏里充满了血液， 而造成呼吸短促。

en: And that wasn't a difficult diagnosis to make.
zh: 这不是一个困难的诊断。

en: I made it and I set to work treating her.
zh: 作出诊断后我开始着手帮她治疗。

en: I gave her aspirin. I gave her medications to relieve the strain on her heart.
zh: 我开给了她阿司匹林，并给了她一些可以减轻她心脏负担的药物。

en: I gave her medications that we call diuretics, water pills,  to get her to pee out the access fluid.
zh: 我还给了她一些利尿剂，俗称水丸， 帮助她将体内多余的水分排出。

en: And that's when I made my first mistake;  I sent her home.
zh: 而就在此时我犯了第一个错误： 我让她回了家。

en: I didn't pick up the phone and do what I was supposed to do,  which was call my attending and run the story by him  so he would have a chance to see her for himself.
zh: 我没有做我照着我应该做的， 拿起电话打给我的主治并让他看一下这个案例， 给他一个亲自见见这名病患的机会。

en: And he knew her,  he would have been able to furnish additional information about her.
zh: 我的主治认识她， 因此可以提供更详细的病历资料。

en: Maybe I did it for a good reason.
zh: 或许我有这么做的理由。

en: Maybe I wanted to be so successful  and so able to take responsibility  that I would do so  and I would be able to take care of my attending's patients  without even having to contact him.
zh: 也许我太想 可以独当一面， 可以不需要 和我的主治沟通 便照顾好他的病患。

en: The second mistake that I made was worse.
zh: 而我犯的第二个错误更加严重。

en: In sending her home,  I disregarded a little voice deep down inside  that was trying to tell me,  "Goldman, not a good idea. Don't do this."
zh: 在让她回家时， 我忽视了我内心一个微小的声音。 这个声音试图告诉我： “高德曼，这样不好，不要这么做。”

en: In fact, so lacking in confidence was I  that I actually asked the nurse  who was looking after Mrs. Drucker,  "Do you think it's okay if she goes home?"
zh: 其实，当时的我是如此的没有自信， 以至于我甚至向照顾Drucker女士 的护士寻求了意见： “你觉得让她回家好么？”

en: And the nurse thought about it  and said very matter-of-factly, "Yeah, I think she'll do okay."
zh: 那位护士想了想， 然后就事论事的说：“嗯，我觉得没有问题。”

en: All the rest of that day,  that afternoon,  I had this kind of gnawing feeling inside my stomach.
zh: 在接下来的一天中， 那天下午， 我的肠胃有着一种翻滚的感觉。

en: But I carried on with my work.
zh: 但我还是照常的继续工作。

en: And at the end of the day, I packed up to leave the hospital  and walked to the parking lot  to take my car and drive home  when I did something that I don't usually do.
zh: 在工作结束后，我整理了下便离开了医院。 在我走向停车场 去取我的车的路程中， 我做了一件我平常不会做的事情。

en: I walked through the emergency department on my way home.
zh: 我从急诊室借了道。

en: And it was there that another nurse,  not the nurse who was looking after Mrs. Drucker before, but another nurse,  said three words to me  that are the three words  that most emergency physicians I know dread.
zh: 而就在那里，另外一位护士， 不是之前照顾Drucker女士的那位， 对我说了 绝大部分急诊医生 都害怕听到的三个字。

en: Others in medicine dread them as well,  but there's something particular about emergency medicine  because we see patients so fleetingly.
zh: 其他科系的医生也害怕这三个字， 但因为急诊医生看的病人都来去匆匆， 这三个字对我们有着特别的意义。

en: The three words are:  Do you remember?
zh: 这三个字是： 记得吗？

en: "Do you remember that patient you sent home?"
zh: “记得吗？你送回家的那个患者？”

en: "Well she's back,"  in just that tone of voice.
zh: “她又回来了。” 她就用了这样平常的语调。

en: She was back and near death.
zh: 回来时已经濒临死亡。

en: About an hour after she had arrived home,  after I'd sent her home,  she collapsed and her family called 911  and the paramedics brought her back to the emergency department  where she had a blood pressure of 50,  which is in severe shock.
zh: 在我让她回家后 大约一个小时后， 她昏倒在了地上，她的家人打了911， 急救人员将她重新带回了急诊室。 此时的她已严重休克， 血压只有 50。

en: And she was barely breathing and she was blue.
zh: 她的呼吸极其微弱，面色发青。

en: They gave her medications to raise her blood pressure.
zh: 他们给了她提升血压的药物，

en: They put her on a ventilator.
zh: 并将她连接上了人工呼吸器。

en: And over the next two or three days,  it was clear that she was never going to wake up.
zh: 但在接下来的两三天中， 她再也不会醒来的可能性越来越大。

en: And the family gathered.
zh: 她的家人聚在了一起。

en: And over the course of the next eight or nine days,  they resigned themselves to what was happening.
zh: 在接下来的八到九天里， 他们慢慢的接受了这件事实。

en: They say you never forget the names  of those who die.
zh: 有人说你永远不会忘记那些 (因你的疏忽而过世的）人的名字，

en: And that was my first time to be acquainted with that.
zh: 而那是我第一次意识到这句话的现实。

en: Over the next few weeks,  I beat myself up  and I experienced for the first time  the unhealthy shame that exists  in our culture of medicine --  where I felt alone, isolated,  not feeling the healthy kind of shame that you feel,  because you can't talk about it with your colleagues.
zh: 在接下来的几个星期内， 我无比的沮丧， 并第一次经历了 那种在医学文化中存在的 危险的羞愧感 -- 我觉得孤单无助。 这不是那种健康的羞愧感， 因为你不能和你的同事提起讨论它。

en: You know that healthy kind,  when you betray a secret that a best friend made you promise never to reveal  and then you get busted  and then your best friend confronts you  and you have terrible discussions,  but at the end of it all that sick feeling guides you  and you say, I'll never make that mistake again.
zh: – 就是那种， 当你背叛了对挚友的承诺而说出了答应要保守的秘密， 并被他知道了以后， 你的挚友找你算账时， 虽然你们会争执不休， 但最后那层罪恶感仍然会主导你， 你告诉自己，我绝对不会再犯同样的错误。

en: And you make amends and you never make that mistake again.
zh: 如是，你做了修正的承诺，然后你永不会再犯那样的错。

en: That's the kind of shame that is a teacher.
zh: 这种羞愧有着教导的作用。

en: The unhealthy shame I'm talking about  is the one that makes you so sick inside.
zh: 而我所说的那种非良性的羞愧 会让你愧对于心。

en: It's the one that says,  not that what you did was bad,  but that you are bad.
zh: 它会对你说， 并非你做的是错的， 而是你根本就是坏人。

en: And it was what I was feeling.
zh: 这便是我当时的感觉。

en: He talked to the family, and I'm quite sure that he smoothed things over  and made sure that I didn't get sued.
zh: 他和那家人好好的谈过。我确定他为了确保 我没有被控告而替我打了圆场。

en: And I kept asking myself these questions.
zh: 但我仍然不断问我自己这些问题：

en: Slowly but surely,  it lifted.
zh: 慢慢的但稳定地， 那糟糕的感觉开始淡化了。

en: And I made myself a bargain  that if only I redouble my efforts to be perfect  and never make another mistake again,  please make the voices stop.
zh: 然后我和自己做了一个约定： 如果我加倍努力做到完美， 不再犯错， 请就此让那自责的声音消去。

en: And they did.
zh: 那个声音的确停止了。

en: And then it happened again.
zh: 但错误又发生了。

en: It was busy, I was in a bit of a hurry.
zh: 当时诊所很忙，所以我也有些急。

en: He kept pointing here.
zh: 他不停的指着这里。

en: I looked at his throat, it was a little bit pink.
zh: 我看了看，他的喉咙有些红肿。

en: And I gave him a prescription for penicillin  and sent him on his way.
zh: 我给他开了盘尼西林的处方后 便让他离开了。

en: And two days later I came to do my next emergency shift,  and that's when my chief asked to speak to me quietly in her office.
zh: 两天后，又轮到我在急诊室值班。 那时我的主任要我去她的办公室里私下谈谈。

en: And she said the three words:  Do you remember?
zh: 她说了那三个字： 记得吗？

en: Well it turns out, he didn't have a strep throat.
zh: 原来，他并没有得链球菌性咽喉炎。

en: He had a potentially life-threatening condition  called epiglottitis.
zh: 得的是一种有可能威胁到生命的病症， 叫会厌炎。

en: You can Google it,  but it's an infection, not of the throat, but of the upper airway,  and it can actually cause the airway to close.
zh: 各位可以在谷歌上查询， 但它不是喉咙，而是上呼吸道的感染， 并有可能造成呼吸道阻塞。

en: He was placed on intravenous antibiotics  and he recovered after a few days.
zh: 在被安排做抗生素静脉注射的几天之后， 他便痊愈了。

en: And I went through the same period of shame and recriminations  and felt cleansed and went back to work,  until it happened again and again and again.
zh: 而我又回到了那个愧疚和自责的时光中， 然后等情绪平复后，又回到了工作岗位， 直到这些错误再度重复的发生。

en: Now that takes some doing,  especially when you work in a hospital  that at the time saw but 14 people a night.
zh: 这是很难想象会发生的事情， 尤其是当你在一间一个晚上 只见十四名病患的医院工作。

en: Now in both cases, I didn't send them home  and I don't think there was any gap in their care.
zh: 虽然对这两个病例，我都没有让他们回家， 而我也不觉得在治疗照顾过程中有任何空隙和差错。

en: One I thought had a kidney stone.
zh: 其中一位我诊断他有肾结石，

en: I ordered a kidney X-ray. When it turned out to be normal,  my colleague who was doing a reassessment of the patient  noticed some tenderness in the right lower quadrant and called the surgeons.
zh: 并安排了肾脏X光，但结果正常。 我的同事当时正在对病人的病情做重新的诊断。 在他留意到病人右下腹的地方有些柔软时，便联系了外科医生。

en: In both cases,  they had their operations and they did okay.
zh: 这两名病患 都做了手术并康复了。

en: But each time,  they were gnawing at me, eating at me.
zh: 但每当我想到这两起病例， 那种感觉都会折磨啃噬我。

en: And I'd like to be able to say to you  that my worst mistakes only happened in the first five years of practice  as many of my colleagues say, which is total B.S.
zh: 而我也希望我可以告诉你 我造成的最严重的错误只发生在了我开始行医的前五年， 像我众多的同事所称一般。但这完全是扯淡。

en: Some of my doozies have been in the last five years.
zh: 在最近的五年中，我也犯了一些错误。

en: Alone, ashamed and unsupported.
zh: 我依然觉得孤独，羞愧，无助。

en: Here's the problem:  If I can't come clean  and talk about my mistakes,  if I can't find the still-small voice  that tells me what really happened,  how can I share it with my colleagues?
zh: 但问题的症结是： 如果我不能理清 和谈论我所犯过的错误， 如果我无法找到那可以告诉我错误的源头的 那仍然微小的声音， 我又如何能和我的同事分享我的经验？

en: How can I teach them about what I did  so that they don't do the same thing?
zh: 我又如何教导他们， 让他们不再重蹈我的覆辙？

en: If I were to walk into a room --  like right now, I have no idea what you think of me.
zh: 当我走入一个场合时 -- 就像现在，我完全不知道各位如何看待我。

en: Oh yeah, you go to a cocktail party  and you might hear about some other doctor,  but you're not going to hear somebody  talking about their own mistakes.
zh: 是的，如果你们去参加一场聚会， 你或许会听到某些关于其他医生的错误的闲聊， 但你不会听到有人 谈论自己所犯的错误。

en: If I were to walk into a room filled with my colleages  and ask for their support right now  and start to tell what I've just told you right now,  I probably wouldn't get through two of those stories  before they would start to get really uncomfortable,  somebody would crack a joke,  they'd change the subject and we would move on.
zh: 如果我现在走入一间坐满我的同事的房间， 向他们寻求帮助 并开始和他们说我刚才告诉各位的事情， 或许在我还没讲超过两个故事之前， 他们就会开始感到非常的不自在。 有人就会讲个笑话， 然后他们会改变话题。

en: And in fact, if I knew and my colleagues knew  that one of my orthopedic colleagues took off the wrong leg in my hospital,  believe me, I'd have trouble  making eye contact with that person.
zh: 事实上，如果我，或者我的同事， 知道医院中一位骨科的同事帮病人截错了腿， 相信我，当我遇到他时， 我也无法与他有正常眼神的交汇。

en: That's the system that we have.
zh: 这就是我们所拥有的体系 --

en: It's a complete denial of mistakes.
zh: 一个完完全全的否定错误的体系。

en: It's a system  in which there are two kinds of physicians --  those who make mistakes  and those who don't,  those who can't handle sleep deprivation and those who can,  those who have lousy outcomes  and those who have great outcomes.
zh: 在这个制度当中 只有两种人 -- 犯错的 不犯错的， 可以调适睡眠不足的和不可以忍受的， 以及那些有着糟糕的结果 和有着优秀的结果的。

en: And it's almost like an ideological reaction,  like the antibodies begin to attack that person.
zh: 这几乎就像免疫系统的自我反应， 像抗体一般开始攻击那个不一样的人。

en: And we have this idea  that if we drive the people who make mistakes  out of medicine,  what will we be left with, but a safe system.
zh: 我们有着一种想法： 当我们将所有的会犯错的人 赶出医学界后， 我们便会得到一个安全的系统。

en: But there are two problems with that.
zh: 但这种想法会衍生出两个问题。

en: In my 20 years or so  of medical broadcasting and journalism,  I've made a personal study of medical malpractice and medical errors  to learn everything I can,  from one of the first articles I wrote for the Toronto Star  to my show "White Coat, Black Art."
zh: 在我二十余年的 医疗广播和新闻工作中， 从我为多伦多星报所写的第一篇文章 到我的节目《白袍魔艺》， 我自行研究了我可以接触到的 一切医疗疏失和医疗错误。

en: And what I've learned  is that errors are absolutely ubiquitous.
zh: 而我所学到的， 便是错误绝对是无处不在。

en: In the United States, the Institute of Medicine pegged it at 100,000.
zh: 在美国，据医学学院统计，这个人数达到了10万之多。

en: In both cases, these are gross underestimates,  because we really aren't ferreting out the problem  as we should.
zh: 即使如此，这两项数据也还是过于低估了现实， 因为我们从未像我们该做的那般 深入地探究这个问题。

en: In a hospital system  where medical knowledge is doubling  every two or three years, we can't keep up with it.
zh: 在一个医疗知识 以两到三年为单位成倍增长的 医院体系中，我们无法紧跟着这些知识的增长。

en: We can't get rid of it.
zh: 而我们也无法摆脱这个问题。

en: We have our cognitive biases,  so that I can take a perfect history on a patient with chest pain.
zh: 我们自己的直觉偏差也会直接影响到我们的结论。 比如说，我可以为一位胸痛的病人记录下完美的病历。

en: Now take the same patient with chest pain,  make them moist and garrulous  and put a little bit of alcohol on their breath,  and suddenly my history is laced with contempt.
zh: 但如果这位同样的胸痛的病人 当时胡言乱语 再加上呼吸带着些许的酒精味的话， 我写下的病历便会挟带着些许的轻蔑。

en: I don't take the same history.
zh: 而这份病历便会截然不同。

en: I'm not a robot;  I don't do things the same way each time.
zh: 我不是机器人， 不会每次都做同样的事情。

en: And my patients aren't cars;  they don't tell me their symptoms in the same way each time.
zh: 我的病患也不是车子， 他们不会每次都用相同的方式去描述他们的症状。

en: Given all of that, mistakes are inevitable.
zh: 因此错误是无可避免的。

en: So if you take the system, as I was taught,  and weed out all the error-prone health professionals,  well there won't be anybody left.
zh: 如果真像我被教导的体系那般 赶出所有易出错的医护专业人员， 那么这个领域便不会有人留下。

en: And you know that business  about people not wanting  to talk about their worst cases?
zh: 还有就是关于 人们不愿 谈论他们所犯的最糟糕的错误一事。

en: On my show, on "White Coat, Black Art,"  I made it a habit of saying, "Here's my worst mistake,"  I would say to everybody  from paramedics to the chief of cardiac surgery,  "Here's my worst mistake," blah, blah, blah, blah, blah,  "What about yours?" and I would point the microphone towards them.
zh: 在我的节目《白袍魔艺》中， 我已经会习惯性地说：“这是我最糟糕的错误”。 我会对从急救医士 到心脏外科首席医师的每个人这么说： “这是我最糟糕的错误，如是，如是。” 然后我会把麦克风递给他们，问：“你呢？”

en: What they need is an environment to be able to do that.
zh: 他们只是需要一个场合来吐露心声。

en: What they need is a redefined medical culture.
zh: 他们需要的是一个重新定义的医学文化，

en: And it starts with one physician at a time.
zh: 从一位又一位个别的医生开始。

en: The redefined physician is human,  knows she's human,  accepts it, isn't proud of making mistakes,  but strives to learn one thing  from what happened  that she can teach to somebody else.
zh: 重新定义过的医生也是人类， 明白她自己是人， 并接受这个事实。她并不觉得犯错误是光荣的， 却可以 从其中学习 并教于他人。

en: She shares her experience with others.
zh: 她会与他人分享她的经验，

en: She's supportive when other people talk about their mistakes.
zh: 并在别人谈论自己过错的时候给于支持。

en: And she points out other people's mistakes,  not in a gotcha way,  but in a loving, supportive way  so that everybody can benefit.
zh: 她不会有一种落井下石的心态， 而会以一种 可以让每个人都从中受惠的关怀，了解的方式 来指出他人的错误。

en: And she works in a culture of medicine  that acknowledges  that human beings run the system,  and when human beings run the system, they will make mistakes from time to time.
zh: 而她所工作的医学文化 承认 整个体系是由人在运作， 而当人在运作一个体系的时候，时不时地错误在所难免。

en: So the system is evolving  to create backups  that make it easier to detect those mistakes  that humans inevitably make  and also fosters in a loving, supportive way  places where everybody who is observing  in the health care system  can actually point out things that could be potential mistakes  and is rewarded for doing so, and especially people like me, when we do make mistakes,  we're rewarded for coming clean.
zh: 这样系统才可以不断地进化改革， 产生可以让人更加容易察觉 这些无法避免的错误的 补救方案。 与此同时，我们可以培养一个热心关怀的工作环境， 鼓励每一位 在观察我们的 医疗系统的人 随时指出一些潜在的错误。 尤其是鼓励像我一样的人，当我们犯错后， 我们可以去正面面对并加以改正。

en: I'm sorry about that,  but I strive to learn one thing  that I can pass on to other people.
zh: 我为此感到抱歉， 但我会尽力从中学习 并教于他人。

en: I still don't know what you think of me,  but I can live with that.
zh: 我仍然不知各位如何看待我， 但我想我对此可以接受。

en: And let me close with three words of my own:  I do remember.
zh: 最后让我以我自己的三个字做为结语： 我记得。

en: There was also recently a study done with CEOs  in which they followed CEOs around for a whole week.
zh: 另外最近还有一个对于CEO们的研究 科学家们在一星期中跟着CEO们

en: And these scientists simply documented all the various tasks  that these CEOs engaged in  and how much time they spent engaging  in making decisions related to these tasks.
zh: 然后记录下他们所参与和完成的 各种不同的活动与任务 和他们做的所有与这些任务有关的 决定所用的时间。

en: And they found that the average CEO  engaged in about 139 tasks in a week.
zh: 科学家们由此发现，每一个CEO平均 每周参与完成大概139个任务。

en: Only about 12 percent of the decisions  did they make an hour or more of their time.
zh: 只有其中百分之十二的决定， 用了他们一小时或更长的时间。

en: Do you know how many choices  make it into your nine minute category  versus your one hour category? How well do you think you're doing  at managing those choices?
zh: 你知道它们中多少 是“九分钟抉择” 又有多少是一小时的选择？ 在管理这些选择上， 你做的如何？

en: Today I want to talk  about one of the biggest modern day choosing problems that we have,  which is the choice overload problem.
zh: 今天我要讲一讲 现在社会中我们所面对的最严重的选择问题： 选择过多。

en: So when I ask you a question,  since I'm blind,  only raise your hand if you want to burn off some calories.
zh: 所以当我问你们一个问题 由于我看不见， 不要举手除非你只是想消耗一下卡路里。

en: Otherwise, when I ask you a question,  and if your answer is yes,  I'd like you to clap your hands.
zh: （笑声) 否则，当我问你们一个问题， 如果你的答案是：是， 我希望你们可以鼓掌。

en: Thank you.
zh: （观众鼓掌） 谢谢

en: So when I was a graduate student at Stanford University,  I used to go to this very, very upscale grocery store;  at least at that time it was truly upscale.
zh: 当我还是斯坦福大学的一名本科学生时， 我经常去一个非常高级的杂货店； 至少在当时看来那家店是十分高级的。

en: Now this store, it was almost like going to an amusement park.
zh: 去那家店，就像是去游乐园一样。

en: I used to love going to this store,  but on one occasion I asked myself,  well how come you never buy anything?
zh: 我过去十分喜欢去这家店， 但是有一次我问自己， 为什么你从来都不买东西呢？

en: Here's their olive oil aisle.
zh: 这是卖橄榄油的过道。

en: They had over 75 different kinds of olive oil,  including those that were in a locked case  that came from thousand-year-old olive trees.
zh: 他们有75种以上不同的橄榄油， 包括那些被锁在盒子里 从4000年的橄榄树上取来的油。

en: So I one day decided to pay a visit to the manager,  and I asked the manager,  "Is this model of offering people all this choice really working?"
zh: 于是有一天我决定去拜访一下这家店的经理， 我问他， “这个给人们所有选择的模型真的有用么？”

en: We decided to do a little experiment,  and we picked jam for our experiment.
zh: 我们决定做一个小实验， 然后选择了果酱作为试验品。

en: Here's their jam aisle.
zh: 这是卖果酱的走廊。

en: We there put out six different flavors of jam  or 24 different flavors of jam,  and we looked at two things:  First, in which case  were people more likely to stop, sample some jam?
zh: 我们在那儿摆6种 或24种不同味道的果酱， 然后我们观察了两件事： 第一，人们在哪种情况下 更愿意停下脚步品尝一些果酱？

en: More people stopped when there were 24, about 60 percent,  than when there were six,  about 40 percent.
zh: 相比较下，大部分，约60%的人，在有24种果酱走廊停了脚步， 而当有6种果酱时 只有40%的人。

en: Of the people who stopped when there were 24,  only three percent of them actually bought a jar of jam.
zh: 在那些在有24种果酱时停下的人们中， 只有3%的人真正买了果酱。

en: Of the people who stopped when there were six,  well now we saw that 30 percent of them  actually bought a jar of jam.
zh: 而此时，在那些在有6种果酱时停下的人们中， 我们发现有30%的人 买了果酱。

en: Now if you do the math,  people were at least six times more likely to buy a jar of jam  Now choosing not to buy a jar of jam  is probably good for us --  at least it's good for our waistlines --  but it turns out that this choice overload problem affects us  even in very consequential decisions. We choose not to choose,  even when it goes against our best self-interests.
zh: 现在如果你算一下的话， 当人们只有六种选择时， 比有24种时 买果酱的倾向上升了至少六倍 选择不买果酱 也许对我们来说是一件好事儿 至少对我们的水桶腰来说， 但是结果证明过度选择甚至在 非常重要的决定上影响我们。 我们甚至在有悖个人利益的情况下， 宁愿放弃选择。

en: So now for the topic of today: financial savings.
zh: 所以现在来介绍我们今天的话题：金融理财。

en: Now I'm going to describe to you a study I did with Gur Huberman, Emir Kamenica, Wei Jang  where we looked at the retirement savings decisions  of nearly a million Americans  from about 650 plans  all in the U.S.
zh: 现在我要向你们介绍我与Gur Huberman, Emir Kamerica, Wei Jang 一起做的一个关于 近百万美国人在全美650多种 养老金计划中 选择的

en: And what we looked at  was whether the number of fund offerings  available in a retirement savings plan,  the 401 plan,  does that affect people's likelihood  to save more for tomorrow.
zh: 研究。 我们研究了 养老金计划， 也就是401（k)雇员福利中 所提供的基金选择数量， 是否影响人们 为未来存款的几率。

en: And what we found  was that indeed there was a correlation.
zh: 我们发现， 这之前却是有联系。

en: So in these plans, we had about 657 plans  that ranged from offering people  anywhere from two to 59 different fund offerings.
zh: 于是在这些计划中，我们选择了657个 从提供2到59种基金 的不同计划。

en: And what we found was that,  the more funds offered,  indeed, there was less participation rate.
zh: 我们发现， 事实上，提供的基金越多， 参购率就越低。

en: So if you look at the extremes,  those plans that offered you two funds,  participation rates were around in the mid-70s --  still not as high as we want it to be.
zh: 所以如果观察一下极端的情况的话， 会发现那些提供给客户两种基金的计划 的参购率在70左右， 仍然没有我们期待中的那么高。

en: In those plans that offered nearly 60 funds,  participation rates have now dropped  to about the 60th percentile.
zh: 那些提供接近60种基金的计划， 参购率降低到了 60多的参购率。

en: Now it turns out  that even if you do choose to participate  when there are more choices present,  even then, it has negative consequences.
zh: 由此看来， 即使是你真的选择参与一个计划， 当那么多计划摆在你面前时， 还是会造成负面的影响。

en: The more choices available,  the more likely they were  to put all their money in pure money market accounts.
zh: 选择越多， 越容易造成人们 把钱存进单纯的存钱账户中。

en: Now neither of these extreme decisions  are the kinds of decisions  that any of us would recommend for people  when you're considering their future financial well-being.
zh: 现在，这两种极端选择 没有一种是当考虑到朋友未来的生活时， 我们会推荐给朋友的 好的选择。

en: They're more likely to delay choosing --  procrastinate even when it goes against their best self-interest.
zh: 所造成的负面影响 他们越来越容易推迟选择的过程， 即使这样做会损害到自身的利益。

en: They're more likely to make worse choices --  worse financial choices, medical choices.
zh: 人们更容易做出更差的选择- 更差的理财选择，医疗选择。

en: They're more likely to choose things that make them less satisfied,  even when they do objectively better.
zh: 人们更容易选择那些令自己不满意的选项， 即使那些选择也许客观来讲并没有那么差。

en: The main reason for this  is because, we might enjoy gazing at those giant walls  of mayonnaises, mustards, vinegars, jams,  but we can't actually do the math of comparing and contrasting  and actually picking from that stunning display.
zh: 这是因为， 虽然我们很享受看一排一排 由美乃滋，黄芥末，醋和果酱建成的的高墙， 却不愿意亲自比较 然后在如此庞大的陈列中做出选择。

en: So what I want to propose to you today  are four simple techniques --  techniques that we have tested in one way or another  in different research venues --  that you can easily apply  in your businesses.
zh: 所以今天我想向你们介绍 四种简单的技巧- 它们都是你可以轻松地 运用在生意上， 并且被测试过许多次的 可靠技巧。

en: You've heard it said before,  but it's never been more true than today,  that less is more.
zh: 你们以前也许听过， 但这个说法在从前的社会从未像现今一样的适用- “少即是多”

en: They're always worried they're going to lose shelf space.
zh: 他们担心这样做会导致他们丢失自我空间。

en: But in fact, what we're seeing more and more  is that if you are willing to cut,  get rid of those extraneous redundant options,  well there's an increase in sales,  there's a lowering of costs,  there is an improvement of the choosing experience.
zh: 但事实上，根据我们所观察到的是 当一个人越是愿意 放弃多余的选择， 使得营业额上升， 价格降低， 越是会改善原则的经历。

en: When Proctor & Gamble  went from 26 different kinds of Head & Shoulders to 15,  they saw an increase in sales by 10 percent.
zh: 当保洁公司 将26种不同的海飞丝减至15种时， 销售额上升了百分之十。

en: When the Golden Cat Corporation  got rid of their 10 worst-selling cat litter products,  they saw an increase in profits  by 87 percent --  a function of both increase in sales  and lowering of costs.
zh: 当金猫公司 停止了他们的十种销售量最差的猫粮的销售， 盈利上升了 百分之八十七- 是又能增加销售额 还降低了成本两全其美的好方法。

en: But the ninth largest retailer,  the ninth biggest retailer in the world today  is Aldi,  and it offers you only 1,400 products --  one kind of canned tomato sauce.
zh: 但是，第九大的零售商 今天世界上第九大的零售商， 是阿尔迪， 而他们只提供给顾客1400种商品- 一种罐装番茄酱。

en: Now in the financial savings world,  I think one of the best examples that has recently come out  on how to best manage the choice offerings  has actually been something that David Laibson was heavily involved in designing,  which was the program that they have at Harvard.
zh: 在这个理财的世界中， 我认为在关于如何最有效地管理选择中 最好的例子是 David Laibson十分投入的 一个哈佛的项目。

en: For those people who actually want to choose,  they're given 20 funds,  not 300 or more funds.
zh: 那些愿意自己选择的人， 有20种不同的基金选择， 而不是300种甚至更多。

en: And the first thing I do is I ask the employees,  "Tell me how these choices are different from one another.
zh: 所以我做的第一件事是问这些教职工， “告诉我这些选择与其他那些有何不同，

en: Now before we started our session this afternoon,  I had a chat with Gary.
zh: 今天下午在这个活动开始之前， 我跟Gary聊了一会儿。

en: And Gary said that he would be willing  to offer people in this audience  an all-expenses-paid free vacation to the most beautiful road in the world.
zh: Gary跟我说他愿意 为今天在场的所有观众提供 一次到这个世界上最美的路的旅行，

en: And I'd like you to read it.
zh: 我希望你们读一下 对这条路的描写。

en: And now I'll give you a few seconds to read it  if you're ready to take Gary up on his offer.
zh: 现在我给你们几秒钟自己读一下， 如果你愿意接受Gary的提议的话，

en: Okay. Anybody who's ready to take him up on his offer.
zh: 就请鼓掌。  好，有人愿意接受他的提议么？

en: Is that all?
zh: 没有其他人了么？

en: All right, let me show you some more about this.
zh: 好吧，我多给你们看一些有关此事的。

en: You guys knew there was a trick, didn't you.
zh: 你们早就知道这是个诡计了，是吧？

en: Now in fact,  you had objectively more information  the first time around than the second time around,  but I would venture to guess  that you felt that it was more real the second time around.
zh: 事实上， 客观地来讲， 你们第一次的时候比第二次得到的信息要多， 但是我冒昧地猜 你们觉得第二次更真实一些。

en: Because the pictures made it feel  more real to you.
zh: 因为那些照片让你们 感觉更真实。

en: Which brings me to the second technique  for handling the choice overload problem,  which is concretization.
zh: 而这个例子就是我们今天要讲的第二个 处理选择过多的技巧， 具体化。

en: Why do people spend an average of 15 to 30 percent more  when they use an ATM card or a credit card  as opposed to cash?
zh: 为什么人们平均每天花 比用现今多15%到30%的时间 在自动提款机或信用卡上呢？

en: Because it doesn't feel like real money.
zh: 因为那样感觉不像是真正的钱。

en: And it turns out  that making it feel more concrete  can actually be a very positive tool  to use in getting people to save more.
zh: 所以 原来使感觉更具体化 可以成为令人们节约的 好方法。

en: So a study that I did with Shlomo Benartzi  and Alessandro Previtero,  we did a study with people at ING --  employees that are all working at ING --  and now these people were all in a session  where they're doing enrollment for their 401 plan.
zh: 所以在一个我与Shlomo Benartzi 和Alessandro Precitero做的研究中， 我们和所有ING的 员工一起做了一个研究， 所有人都参加了一个 一起注册401雇员福利的会议。

en: And during that session,  we kept the session exactly the way it used to be,  but we added one little thing.
zh: 在这个过程中 我们在保持每个会议完全相同的情况下， 加了一个小东西。

en: The one little thing we added  was we asked people  to just think about all the positive things that would happen in your life  By doing that simple thing,  there was an increase in enrollment by 20 percent  and there was an increase in the amount of people willing to save  or the amount that they were willing to put down into their savings account  by four percent.
zh: 我们加的是， 让他们 每个人都想象如果多存一些 生命中可能会发生的那些美好的事情。 仅仅是这样做后， 参与率上升了百分之二十， 人们愿意存钱的数额或者说是 愿意放进自己储蓄账户的金额增长了 百分之四。

en: We can handle more categories  than we can handle choices.
zh: 相比处理选择来说， 我们可以轻松处理更多类别。

en: It turns out that in Wegmans grocery stores  up and down the northeast corridor,  the magazine aisles range anywhere  from 331 different kinds of magazines  all the way up to 664.
zh: 发现在Wegmans百货商店中， 在东北走廊的地方， 买杂志的那一栏 有331到 甚至664种杂志。

en: But you know what?
zh: 但是你们知道么？

en: If I show you 600 magazines  and I divide them up into 10 categories,  versus I show you 400 magazines  and divide them up into 20 categories,  you believe that I have given you  more choice and a better choosing experience  if I gave you the 400  than if I gave you the 600.
zh: 如果我先给你们看600本杂志， 然后把它们分成10类， 然后再给你们看400本杂志， 但是分成20类， 你们会相信， 当我给你们看 400本杂志时 比给你们600本时的选择更多，选择体验更好。

en: Here are two different jewelry displays.
zh: 这里有两个不同的珠宝展示，

en: If you think the display on the left is Swing  and the display on the right is Jazz,  clap your hands.
zh: 如果你觉得左边的是“摇摆” 右边的是“爵士” 就请鼓掌。

en: Okay, there's some.
zh: 好吧，有一些。

en: If you think the one on the left is Jazz and the one on the right is Swing,  clap your hands.
zh: 如果你觉得左边的是“爵士”， 右边的是“摇摆” 请鼓掌。

en: Now it turns out you're right.
zh: 你们是对的。

en: The one on the left is Jazz and the one on the right is Swing,  but you know what?
zh: 左边的的确是“爵士”，而右边的正是“摇摆”， 但是你知道么？

en: This is a highly useless categorization scheme.
zh: 这是一个十分无用的分类阴谋。

en: The categories need to say something  to the chooser, not the choice-maker.
zh: 类别必须可以告诉 选择者一些事情，而不是创造选择的人。

en: And you often see that problem  when it comes down to those long lists of all these funds.
zh: 你们也许可以在 那些冗长的基金名单中看到这个问题。

en: Who are they actually supposed to be informing?
zh: 到底谁才是应该得到信息的人呢？

en: It turns out we can actually  handle a lot more information than we think we can,  we've just got to take it a little easier.
zh: 事实上，我们所能 承受的信息量比我们想象的要高， 我们需要做的就是用轻松地面度对待。

en: I'm going to show you one example of what I'm talking about.
zh: 现在我给你们举一个有关的例子。

en: Here's a German car manufacturer  that gives you the opportunity to completely custom make your car.
zh: 现在有一个德国制造商， 愿意让你定制一辆完全个性化的车。

en: You've got to make 60 different decisions,  completely make up your car.
zh: 你必须要做60个不同的决定 才能做好这辆车。

en: Now these decisions vary  in the number of choices that they offer per decision.
zh: 这些决定包括 每一个决定所提供的选择。

en: Car colors, exterior car colors --  I've got 56 choices.
zh: 光车的颜色，内置的颜色 就有56种选择。

en: So now what I'm going to do  is I'm going to vary the order in which these decisions appear.
zh: 现在我要做的是 改变这些要做的决定出线的顺序。

en: If you keep hitting the default button per decision,  that means you're getting overwhelmed,  that means I'm losing you.
zh: 如果你不停地按默认选项的话 就说明你已经被选择淹没了， 也就是说我正在失去你的参与。

en: What you find  is the people who go from high choice to low choice,  they're hitting that default button over and over and over again.
zh: 你会发现， 从选择多的开始到选择少的人 会不停地选择默认选项。

en: They go from low choice to high choice,  they're hanging in there.
zh: 那些从选择少开始到选择多的人， 还在坚持着。

en: It's the same information. It's the same number of choices.
zh: 可是他们所得到的信息是完全一样的。所要做的选择也是一样的。

en: The only thing that I have done  is I have varied the order  in which that information is presented.
zh: 我所做的唯一一件事就是 改变了 信息所出现的顺序。

en: Even though choosing gearshift  doesn't tell me anything about my preferences for interior decor,  it still prepares me for how to choose.
zh: 即使选择变速排档 不能说明我对车内颜色的偏好 却仍能教会我如何去选择。

en: It also gets me excited about this big product that I'm putting together,  so I'm more willing to be motivated  to be engaged.
zh: 另一件令我兴奋的事实是我所要组成的是如此一个庞然大物， 所以我变得更有动力 去参与。

en: I have talked about four techniques  for mitigating the problem of choice overload --  cut -- get rid of the extraneous alternatives;  concretize -- make it real;  categorize -- we can handle more categories, less choices;  condition for complexity.
zh: 我讲了四种可以减缓过多选择的 技巧- 精简-放弃没有用的选择； 具体化-让选择变得更真实一些； 分类-我们能承受的类别比选择多； 从简入繁。

en: All of these techniques that I'm describing to you today  are designed to help you manage your choices --  better for you, you can use them on yourself,  better for the people that you are serving.
zh: 今天我所讲的所有技巧， 都是为了帮助你更好地管理选择而设计的- 使用这些技巧对你更好， 也对你所服务的那些人更好。

en: And the more we're able to be choosy about choosing  the better we will be able  to practice the art of choosing.
zh: 我们对选择越是挑剔 就越能 掌握选择的艺术。

en: Thank you very much.
zh: 非常感谢。

en: In the 1980s  in the communist Eastern Germany,  if you owned a typewriter,  you had to register it with the government.
zh: 20世纪80年代 在共产主义的东德， 如果你有一台打字机， 你就得去跟政府登记。

en: And this was done  so the government could track where text was coming from.
zh: 这样做后， 政府就能跟踪文本出自何方。

en: And we in the West  couldn't understand how anybody could do this,  how much this would restrict freedom of speech.
zh: 而在西方 我们不能理解有人怎么能做这种事， 这将会多么限制言论自由啊。

en: But today in 2011,  if you go and buy a color laser printer  from any major laser printer manufacturer  and print a page,  that page will end up  having slight yellow dots  printed on every single page  in a pattern which makes the page unique  to you and to your printer.
zh: 可是，2011年的今天， 如果你从任何一家大型的激光打印机厂商 买一台彩色激光打印机 打印出一页， 这页纸最后 会有一些小黄点 印在每一页上 图案让这页纸是独特 对你和你的打印机都是。

en: This is happening  to us today.
zh: 这就是今天 发生在我们身上的。

en: And nobody seems to be making a fuss about it.
zh: 似乎没有人为此大惊小怪。

en: And this is an example  of the ways  that our own governments  are using technology  against us, the citizens. And this is one of the main three sources  of online problems today.
zh: 这是个 展示 我们的政府 使用科技 来对付我们这些公民们的例子。 这是今天网络问题的

en: Like here, we have Mr. Dimitry Golubov  from the city of Kiev in Ukraine.
zh: 这里，我们有位德米特里 戈卢博夫先生 来自乌克兰的基辅市。

en: They use online attacks  to make lots of money,  and lots and lots of it.
zh: 他们通过在线攻击 赚很多钱， 很多很多钱。

en: We actually have several cases  of millionaires online, multimillionaires,  who made money with their attacks.
zh: 我们实际上有好几个案子 都是在线百万富翁，千万富翁， 都是通过在线攻击赚的。

en: Here's Vladimir Tsastsin form Tartu in Estonia.
zh: 这里还有来自爱沙尼亚的塔尔图的弗拉基米尔·莎斯森。

en: This is Stephen Watt.
zh: 这是斯蒂芬·瓦特

en: This is Bjorn Sundin.
zh: 这是比昂·松丁

en: This is Matthew Anderson, Tariq Al-Daour  and so on and so on.
zh: 这是马修·安德森，塔利克·阿尔杜 等等等等。

en: These guys  make their fortunes online,  but they make it through the illegal means  of using things like banking trojans  to steal money from our bank accounts  while we do online banking,  or with keyloggers  to collect our credit card information  while we are doing online shopping from an infected computer.
zh: 这些人 在线挣了很多钱， 但他们挣的钱是非法的 通过使用类似银行木马 从我们账户偷钱 当我们在网上进行银行业务， 或者使用键盘记录 来收集我们的信用卡信息 当我们通过被感染的电脑来在线购物的时候。

en: The U.S. Secret Service,  two months ago,  froze the Swiss bank account  of Mr. Sam Jain right here,  and that bank account had 14.9 million U.S. dollars on it  Mr. Jain himself is on the loose;  nobody knows where he is.
zh: 美国情报局， 两个月前， 冻结了萨姆 杰恩先生 在瑞士的银行账户， 那个账户冻结的时候 帐上有一千四百九十万美金。 杰恩先生本人仍逍遥法外； 没人知道他在哪。

en: And I claim it's already today  that it's more likely for any of us  to become the victim of a crime online  than here in the real world.
zh: 今天我断言 我们当中的任何一位都有可能 成为在线犯罪的受害者 甚至超越现实世界。

en: And it's very obvious  that this is only going to get worse.
zh: 而且很显然 这种情况越来越糟。

en: So those are the three main attackers:  criminals who do it for the money,  hacktivists like Anonymous  doing it for the protest,  but then the last group are nation states,  governments doing the attacks.
zh: 这些就是三组主要的攻击者： 为了钱的罪犯， 匿名的攻击活跃者 为了抗议而作的， 而最后一组是民族国家， 政府在攻击。

en: And then we look at cases  like what happened in DigiNotar.
zh: 我们看一下例子 就像DigiNotar公司发生的。

en: This is a prime example of what happens  when governments attack  against their own citizens.
zh: 这是政府攻击的 典型例子 来反对自己的民众。

en: Somebody broke in  and they hacked it thoroughly.
zh: 有人闯进去 彻底毁了它。

en: So how do people die  as the result of a hack like this?
zh: 那么，究竟如何人们的死亡 归咎于这样一个攻击呢？

en: Well you need a certificate  if you have a website that has https,  SSL encrypted services,  services like Gmail.
zh: 你需要证书的情况会是 你有一个有https的网站， SSL加密服务， 类似Gmail的服务。

en: Now we all, or a big part of us,  use Gmail or one of their competitors,  but these services are especially popular  in totalitarian states  like Iran,  where dissidents  use foreign services like Gmail  because they know they are more trustworthy than the local services  and they are encrypted over SSL connections,  so the local government can't snoop  on their discussions.
zh: 当今我们所有人或大部分人， 使用Gmail或它对手们中的任何一家， 这些服务在极权主义国家 尤其流行 比如伊朗， 持异议者 使用诸如Gmail的国外服务 因为他们知道这些比当地的服务更可靠 他们通过SSL的连接加密， 所以当地政府窥探不到 他们的讨论。

en: And this is exactly what happened  with the case of DigiNotar.
zh: 这恰恰就是发生在 DigiNotar的案子中。

en: What about Arab Spring  and things that have been happening, for example, in Egypt?
zh: 阿拉伯跳是怎么回事？ 比如说在埃及发生的那些事？

en: And within that binder were notes  from a company based in Germany  which had sold the Egyptian government  a set of tools  for intercepting --  and in very large scale --  all the communication of the citizens of the country.
zh: 夹子中有些笔记 是来自一家德国公司 这家公司卖给埃及政府 一套工具 用来截取-- 很大比例是 国家公众的所有通信。

en: The company headquarters are right here.
zh: 公司的总部就在那里。

en: If you are a suspect in a criminal case,  well it's pretty obvious, your phone will be tapped.
zh: 如果你是一宗刑事案件的嫌疑， 很显然，你的电话会被监听。

en: But today, it goes beyond that.
zh: 可是今天，事情已经超越了。

en: They will even use tools like State Trojan  to infect your computer with a trojan,  which enables them  to watch all your communication,  to listen to your online discussions,  to collect your passwords.
zh: 他们会用类似Scuinst Trojan的工具 用一个木马来感染你的电脑， 这样就让他们 监视你所有的通信， 监听你的在线讨论， 收集你的密码。

en: Now when we think deeper  about things like these,  the obvious response from people should be  that, "Okay, that sounds bad,  but that doesn't really affect me because I'm a legal citizen.
zh: 当我们更深的想一下 这些事情， 人们的反应显然应是 “对啊，听起来很糟糕， 但因为我是合法公民，也不会真正影响我啦。

en: Because I have nothing to hide."
zh: 我没有什么可隐藏的。”

en: And this is an argument,  which doesn't make sense.
zh: 这就是争论所在， 没什么道理。

en: This is not a question  between privacy  against security.
zh: 这不是个 隐私 反对安全的问题。

en: It's a question of freedom  against control.
zh: 而是一个 自由反对管制的问题。

en: And do we trust, do we blindly trust,  any future government,  a government we might have  50 years from now?
zh: 我们会不会信任未来的政府， 盲目地信任， 一个50年后的 政府呢？

en: This is where I live. I live in Kenya,  at the south parts of the Nairobi National Park.
zh: 这是我所生活的地方，肯尼亚， 在内罗毕国家公园的南部

en: Those are my dad's cows at the back,  and behind the cows,  that's the Nairobi National Park.
zh: 在我的身后是我父亲的奶牛 在奶牛的后边 就是内罗毕国家公园

en: Nairobi National Park is not fenced in the south widely,  which means wild animals like zebras  migrate out of the park freely.
zh: 内罗毕国家公园的南部并没有全部围起栅栏 这就意味着像斑马这样的野生动物 可以自由地在公园外移动

en: So predators like lions follow them,  and this is what they do.
zh: 所以像狮子这样的捕食者会跟随他们 这就是他们的所作所为，

en: This is one of the cows which was killed at night,  and I just woke up in the morning and I found it dead,  and I felt so bad,  because it was the only bull we had.
zh: 这就是其中一只在夜晚被杀害的奶牛 我在早晨醒来时就发现它已经死了， 我的心情槽透了， 因为这是我家里唯一的公牛

en: My community, the Maasai, we believe that  we came from heaven with all our animals and all the land  for herding them, and that's why we value them so much.
zh: 我们马赛族的人相信 我们是带着我们的动物和家园从天堂而来 然后放牧、生活，这就是我们为什么如此重视它们。

en: It's one of the six lions which were killed in Nairobi.
zh: 这是他们在内罗毕国家公园杀的六个狮子中的其中一个

en: And I think this is why the Nairobi National Park lions are few.
zh: 我想这就是内罗毕公园的狮子会那么少的原因。

en: So a boy, from six to nine years old, in my community  is responsible for his dad's cows,  and that's the same thing which happened to me.
zh: 在我们家族，凡是六到九岁的男孩 都有肩负着保卫他们父亲奶牛的责任， 同样的事业发生在我身上。

en: And a second idea I got was  to use a scarecrow.
zh: 于是有了第二个办法： 利用稻草人。

en: I was trying to trick the lions  [into thinking] that I was standing near the cowshed.
zh: 我想要欺骗狮子 让它们误以为是我站在牛舍旁边。

en: But lions are very clever.   They will come the first day and they see the scarecrow, and they go back,  but the second day, they'll come and they say,  this thing is not moving here, it's always here.   So he jumps in and kills the animals.
zh: 但是狮子十分聪明。 他们第一天来时看到了稻草人，然后就回去了。 但是第二天，他们会再来并且说： 这个东西从没动过，他一直呆在这儿 所以他们又跳进来，杀死了动物。

en: Since I was a small boy,  I used to work in my room for the whole day,  and I even took apart my mom's new radio,  and that day she almost killed me,  but I learned a lot about electronics.   So I got an old car battery,  an indicator box. It's a small device found in a motorcycle,  and it helps motorists when they want to turn right or left. It blinks.
zh: 因为我当时是个小孩子， 我可以一整天不干别的，在自己的房间里鼓捣一天， 我甚至把我妈妈新买的收音机拆得七零八落， 那天她差点杀了我， 尽管如此，我学到了许多关于电子的知识。 所以我找到了一个旧的车用蓄电池， 一个指示器。这是一个从摩托车中找到的小装备， 用来控制摩托车的转向灯，能够让灯闪烁。

en: And I got a switch where I can switch on the lights, on and off.
zh: 同时我找到了一个开关，可以控制灯的亮灭。

en: And that's a small torch from a broken flashlight.
zh: 灯泡来自于一个坏掉的手电筒。

en: So I set up everything.
zh: 一切都准备好了。

en: And that's how it looks to lions when they come at night.
zh: 当狮子晚上走近的时候看到的就是这个样子。

en: The lights flash and trick  the lions into thinking I was walking around the cowshed,  but I was sleeping in my bed.
zh: 这个灯光一闪动就会使狮子受到欺骗 它们会以为是我在牛棚附近走动， 但实际上，此时的我正在自己的床上做着春秋大梦。

en: So I set it up in my home two years ago,  and since then, we have never experienced any problem with lions.
zh: 我在两年前把这个装置装在了我家中， 从那时起，我们就再没有狮子捕食家禽的烦恼了。

en: She had a lot of her animals being killed by lions,  and she asked me if I could put the lights for her.
zh: 她家有一大堆的家禽被狮子捕食了。 她问我是否可以帮她在家里也装一个这样的灯。

en: Because of this invention, I was lucky to get a scholarship  in one of the best schools in Kenya,  Brookhouse International School,  and I'm really excited about this.
zh: 我也很幸运地因为这项发明而获得了奖学金 这是肯尼亚最好的学校—— 布鲁克豪斯国际学校所颁发的， 我对此感到十分的兴奋。

en: My new school now is coming in and helping  by fundraising and creating an awareness.
zh: 我的新学校现在也加入进来，并帮助我 提高知名度并筹集更多资金。

en: I even took my friends back to my community,  and we're installing the lights to the homes  which don't have [any], and I'm teaching them how to put them.
zh: 我甚至将我的朋友带回我的社区， 帮助他们在没有赶狮灯的人家里安装这个 我教他们怎么安装。

en: So one year ago, I was just a boy in the savanna grassland  herding my father's cows,  and I used to see planes flying over,  and I told myself that one day, I'll be there inside.
zh: 一年前，我只是一个热带大草原上 帮爸爸放牛的普通男孩， 我常常看着飞机飞过， 并且告诉自己：总有一天，我也会在里面。

en: Ashê olên. It means in my language, thank you very much.
zh: 非常感谢（肯尼亚语）。在我的语言里，它的意思是：非常感谢！

en: RT: But I know electric fences are already invented,  but I want to make mine.
zh: RT：我知道，电力栅栏已经有了， 但是我只想做我自己的那一个。

en: CA: You already tried it once, right, and you --RT: I tried it before,  but I stopped because it gave me a shock.   CA: In the trenches. Richard Turere, you are something else.
zh: CA：你已经尝试过一次了，对吧，但是你——RT：我之前有过尝试， 但我停止了，因为它惊吓到我了。 CA：会是一场苦战。Richard Turere，你与众不同。

en: We're going to cheer you on every step of the way, my friend.
zh: 我们将为你在成长中的每一步喝彩，朋友。

en: Thank you so much.RT: Thank you.
zh: 很感谢你。RT：谢谢。

en: And I grew up singing a song called "Nothing To Envy."
zh: 我大一点后学会了一首叫做"无可羡慕"的歌，

en: Although I often wondered about the outside world,  I thought I would spend my entire life in North Korea,  until everything suddenly changed.
zh: 虽然我也时常憧憬外面的世界， 我以为我会在朝鲜度过我的一生， 直到所有事情都忽然改变。

en: When I was seven years old, I saw my first public execution.
zh: 当我七岁的时候，我第一次见证了公开处决，
